scenes.title: INT. A BLACK SCREEN

plotSummary.brief: Opening: Eddie's voiceover reveals he's in mortal danger
plotSummary.detailed: In a flash-forward cold open, Eddie's voice reveals cryptically: 'They found me.' The film opens in media res with immediate tension.
plotSummary.subtext: Hooks the audience with mystery - who is Eddie? Who found him? Why is he in danger? The answer lies in the past.

keyDialogue.quote: They found me.
keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE (V.0.)
keyDialogue.context: During scene

Eddie.arc: At rock bottom before discovering NZT

scenes.significance: Opens the film with mystery and tension, hooks audience

scenes.title: INT. CLOSE 0N - A HIGH-TECH RESIDENTIAL STEEL DOOR

location.primary: CLOSE 0N - A HIGH-TECH RESIDENTIAL STEEL DOOR

plotSummary.brief: Armed men break into Eddie's luxury high-rise apartment
plotSummary.detailed: Professional, determined people pound on Eddie's reinforced steel door with power tools. Despite half-billion dollar building security, they've gotten through. Eddie estimates he has five minutes.
plotSummary.subtext: Eddie has achieved massive wealth (luxury apartment) but it's brought deadly consequences. His success has made him a target.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: I might have five minutes. We hear the WHRRRRR of POWER TOOLS going to work on his door. These people are determined. Professional. And prepared.
keyDialogue.significance: Shows Eddie's initial state before NZT
keyDialogue.context: serious. The door shudders but doesn't give. It's state-of- the-art residential protection.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE  (
keyDialogue.quote: I'll never know how they got past security in a half-billion dollar building.
keyDialogue.context: serious. The door shudders but doesn't give. It's state-of- the-art residential protection.

scenes.title: EXT. THE CELESTIAL - LOOKING INTO THE LOBBY - NIGHT

location.primary: THE CELESTIAL - LOOKING INTO THE LOBBY

plotSummary.brief: Eddie stands on his terrace ledge, about to jump as neighbor is killed
plotSummary.detailed: Eddie stands on the exterior ledge of his 80-floor penthouse terrace, prepared to jump rather than be caught. Through adjoining windows, he sees his neighbor shot dead for opening his door. Eddie reflects bitterly on coming so close to 'becoming the perfect version of ourselves' and having an impact, only to end up impacting the sidewalk.
plotSummary.subtext: The entire film's central question: what does it mean to become perfect? Eddie achieved it and now faces death. Was it worth it? The film will flash back to answer.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: They've become sophisticated. Before they couldn't have done this. But now...? The CAMERA RISES, breathlessly, in a blur, up all 80 floors of this stunning new building, coming to rest on...
keyDialogue.significance: Shows Eddie's initial state before NZT

scenes.title: EXT. NEW YORK CITY STREET - DAY

plotSummary.brief: Flashback: Eddie as a struggling, out-of-shape writer eating falafel
plotSummary.detailed: Contrast to the sleek future Eddie: messy hair, schlumy clothes, overweight with belly bulge, wearing a worn corduroy jacket. He's a writer who, two years after being fired from copywriting, bullshitted his way into a book contract.
plotSummary.subtext: The 'before' picture. Eddie is at rock bottom - physically, professionally, emotionally. This sets up the dramatic transformation to come.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: Not so long ago, this was me. Eddie is walking down the street, messily eating a street falafel. His hair is longer, his clothes schlumpier, his face rounder --he's out of shape. A belly bulges against his belt. He wears jeans and that worn-out corduroy "writer's" sport coat --the one that your girlfriend fights to give to the Salvation Army.
keyDialogue.significance: Shows Eddie's initial state before NZT
keyDialogue.context: During scene

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: I was a writer. Two years after my copywriting job at Dexter & Kerr came to a non-mutual end, I had, in an extraordinary burst of desperate energy, bullshitted my way into my first book contract. This was it:
keyDialogue.significance: Eddie's failed writing career and creative block
keyDialogue.context: During scene

scenes.title: INT. EDDIE'S RATTY RENT-CONTROLLED APARTMENT ON AVENUE A- DAY

location.primary: EDDIE'S RATTY RENT-CONTROLLED APARTMENT ON AVENUE A
location.description: Eddie's cramped, messy rent-controlled apartment on Avenue A

plotSummary.brief: Eddie procrastinates instead of writing: computer games, TV, sleeping
plotSummary.detailed: Quick cuts show Eddie's 'writer's life': playing computer Scrabble, sprawled watching TV with takeout, sleeping until noon, sitting on the toilet with Game Boy. His phone never rings. Bills pile up. He says he's 'gearing up' and 'getting psyched' but months pass without writing a word.
plotSummary.subtext: Eddie is paralyzed by self-doubt and lack of discipline. The book contract didn't magically grant him ability - he still can't access his potential. He needs external help (foreshadowing NZT).

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: Now, at last, I was ready to write. QUICK CUTS: --Eddie sprawled on the couch, eating takeout and watching TV, the sink in the foreground full of dishes. -- Eddie shooting baskets into a toy hoop.
keyDialogue.significance: Shows Eddie's initial state before NZT
keyDialogue.context: Eddie, slumped in his desk chair, is playing COMPUTER

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: Gearing up, that's all. --Eddie sleeping in his bed, sacked out, the clock beside him clicking to 11:59 a.m.
keyDialogue.context: Eddie, slumped in his desk chair, is playing COMPUTER

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: Getting psyched. --Eddie sitting on the john, playing a game on his childhood Game Boy.
keyDialogue.context: Eddie, slumped in his desk chair, is playing COMPUTER

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE

keyDialogue.context: Eddie, slumped in his desk chair, is playing COMPUTER

scenes.title: INT. A MIDTOWN COFFEE SHOP - DAY

plotSummary.brief: Girlfriend Lindy breaks up with Eddie at coffee shop, returning his key
plotSummary.detailed: Lindy, attractive and professionally dressed, sadly slides Eddie's apartment key across the counter. Eddie is blindsided. She tells him she knows what he does all day, knows 'the good stuff and the shit.' She sees where it's going: he'll lose his apartment, move in with her, she'll eventually boot him out, and he'll end up in his childhood bedroom in Newark. She admits she'd have had him move in anyway - if it was her he wanted, and not his ex-wife Melissa.
plotSummary.subtext: Lindy loves Eddie but can't watch him destroy himself. She's protecting herself from inevitable heartbreak. The Melissa revelation shows Eddie isn't even emotionally available - he's stuck in the past.

keyDialogue.speaker: LINDY
keyDialogue.quote: I don't think I can keep this. Eddie is broadsided. Hurt.
keyDialogue.context: attractive, real-looking girl, late 20's. She's dressed in a professional suit. She looks very sad.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: Just like that. She shoots him a look of almost intolerable sympathy.
keyDialogue.significance: Shows Eddie's initial state before NZT
keyDialogue.context: attractive, real-looking girl, late 20's. She's dressed in a professional suit. She looks very sad.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: I was kind of under the impression you cared a little more than just--
keyDialogue.context: attractive, real-looking girl, late 20's. She's dressed in a professional suit. She looks very sad.

keyDialogue.speaker: LINDY
keyDialogue.quote: If I didn't care, maybe I'd be able to stand to watch you do this.
keyDialogue.context: attractive, real-looking girl, late 20's. She's dressed in a professional suit. She looks very sad.

plotSummary.brief: Flash: Memory of Melissa (Eddie's ex-wife) bending seductively over him
plotSummary.detailed: A brief, beautiful memory in Eddie's POV: a lovely, willowy brunette in an undershirt, intimate and seductive.
plotSummary.subtext: Melissa haunts Eddie. He's chasing a memory of perfection he once had, unable to move forward.

plotSummary.brief: Lindy got her promotion; she pays for coffee as Eddie can't afford it
plotSummary.detailed: Lindy reveals she got the promotion - her own assistant now. Eddie is genuinely happy for her, saying she deserves it. She grabs the check, both knowing Eddie can't pay.
plotSummary.subtext: Lindy is moving up while Eddie spirals down. The gap between them is widening. Her paying symbolizes the power imbalance in their relationship.

keyDialogue.speaker: LINDY
keyDialogue.quote: I have to get back.
keyDialogue.context: shakes her head, looks away. It's clearly over. She gets up. He follows.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: --Hey, well -- wait -- you didn't tell me what happened yesterday. We can see on Lindy's face that she's still vulnerably pleased that Eddie remembered to ask.

scenes.title: EXT. MIDTOWN STREET - DAY

plotSummary.brief: Eddie meets ex-brother-in-law Vernon on the street
plotSummary.detailed: Walking home, eyeing homeless people and feeling his dismal future, Eddie (almost 35) reflects that 'no one talks about potential at 35.' Vernon Gant, his ex-brother-in-law from his marriage to Melissa, approaches with condescending bemusement. Vernon looks rich: expensive suit, clearly comes from money. He whacks Eddie's arms genially, comments on Eddie's weight gain ('pack it on, why don't you?'), and asks if he's still trying to write.
plotSummary.subtext: Vernon represents everything Eddie isn't: successful, wealthy, confident. This chance meeting will change Eddie's life - Vernon has access to NZT.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: She was right. I was almost 35. No one talks about "potential" at 35. I had missed the on-ramp. Soon I'd be sleeping in the lower bunk of my childhood bedroom... my father happy to welcome me into the challenging field of dental supply inventory... He's interrupted by A VOICE - calm, amused:
keyDialogue.significance: Central theme: human potential and transformation
keyDialogue.context: Eddie is walking home, eying the homeless on the street, feeling his dismal future breathing down hi

keyDialogue.quote: Eddie. Morgan. VERNON GANT looks him over with condescending bemusment. He's 30, wears an expensive suit, looks like he comes from money.
keyDialogue.context: Eddie is walking home, eying the homeless on the street, feeling his dismal future breathing down hi

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: Of all the useless relationships better forgotten and put away in mothballs, is there any more useless than... the ex-brother-in- law?

scenes.title: INT. BAR - DAY

plotSummary.brief: Vernon invites Eddie for a beer; Eddie reluctantly agrees
plotSummary.detailed: Vernon is surprised/impressed Eddie has a book contract. When Eddie asks if Vernon is still dealing drugs, Vernon smugly says 'Do I look like I'm still dealing?' Eddie sizes up the suit, shoes, watch, haircut and says 'No.' Vernon invites Eddie for a drink to hear about the book, and when Eddie declines, Vernon plucks his cigarette pack and holds it hostage until Eddie agrees.
plotSummary.subtext: Vernon's wealth came from somewhere - legitimate pharmaceutical consulting or illegal dealing? The answer will matter. Eddie's weakness (cigarette addiction) makes him manipulable.

plotSummary.brief: It's a former tenement, fourth-floor walk-up. Eddie trudges
plotSummary.detailed: It's a former tenement, fourth-floor walk-up. Eddie trudges up the old stairs, the tiny tiles worn away in spots, the Victorian moldings disfigured from a hundred and twenty years of paint. Eddie is suddenly seized by a racking cough -- a horrible smoker's cough that makes him double over. He sounds like he's 80 years old. He finally gets it under control, gets a glimpse of himself in the storefront window. He looks bad, and he knows he looks bad. He reaches into his pocket. THE PILL sits teasin

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: Well. There was less than nothing to lose. Quickly, impulsively, he swallows it. 16.
keyDialogue.context: He reaches into his pocket. THE PILL sits teasingly in the palm of his hand, looking up at him.

keyDialogue.quote: There is absolutely no truth to the rumor of this merger. None whatsoever. My husband is having some tests, this is a difficult time, and I would appreciate your directing further questions to our attorney... She motions at the gentleman next to her. --Who is also Eddie's attorney, MORRIS BRANDT. The one who was so helpful with the police. The one who held his jacket. Bitter amusement in Eddie's eyes. At least he knows. The APARTMENT BUZZER buzzes. Eddie freezes. Looks at the door. It BUZZES again.

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE

keyDialogue.significance: Eddie dealing with consequences of enhanced success

keyDialogue.speaker: EDDIE
keyDialogue.quote: It was my inner door. Someone was in the building, ten feet away, right now. Eddie walks to his phone, picks it up. Pushes the button, puts it to his ear. It's dead. He pushes the "on" button again and again. Nothing. The buzzer BUZZES again. Eddie rushes to the door, opens the COAT CLOSET. In the closet is a state-of-the-art SECURITY MONITOR. Gennady and TWO MEN are outside his door! Suddenly the MONITOR goes BLACK. Eddie flicks the switch on the monitor. Nothing. Eddie flicks the switch again. It's dead. Someone, somewhere, has figured out how to disarm it. The buzzer BUZZES again. Eddie backs away from the door. We HEAR Eddie's shallow, panicked breathing. He lunges for his briefcase, pulls out his CELL PHONE. THE CELL PHONE - CLOSE It reads "No Signal." BAM! The first slam on the door begins. BAM! The second. The door holds, but Eddie begins to back away in horror.

We see Eddie striding down the corridor, wearing a sharp suit, looking more dignified than we've ever seen him, more adult. The snap and crackle of something new -- power -- is in his step.
